document.docAuthor: Burks, Roger A., Heraty, John M., Dominguez, Chrysalyn & Mottern, Jason L.
document.docTitle: Orasema evansi Burks & Heraty & Dominguez & Mottern 2018, n. sp.
document.masterDocTitle: Complex diversity in a mainly tropical group of ant parasitoids: Revision of the Orasema stramineipes species group (Hymenoptera: Chalcidoidea: Eucharitidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Complex diversity in a mainly tropical group of ant parasitoids: Revision of the Orasema stramineipes species group (Hymenoptera: Chalcidoidea: Eucharitidae)

subSubSection.paragraph: urn:lsid:zoobank.org:act:2CBC91DD-A3EF-44FD-B0C1-C1C7605DE6D2 ( Figs 2 , 61–76 )

Orasema
sp. C1 near
costaricensis
; Heraty 1990, 1994b.
Diagnosis. Mesoscutal midlobe and mesoscutellar disc mostly finely reticulate. Mesoscutellar disc with fine sculpture posteromedially. Axillula with parallel carinae and no other sculpture.

This species is most similar to
O. costaricensis
,
O. minutissima
and
O. rapo
. It differs from
O. costaricensis
and
O. minutissima
in lacking reticulate sculpture on the axillula ( Figs 65 , 73 ). It differs from
O. rapo
in having an areolate-reticulate or reticulate, instead of wholly areolate, mesoscutellum ( Figs 64 , 72 ). These differences are slight, but are supported by molecular data.
Description. Female. Length 3.4–4.9 mm .

Color: Head and mesosoma green to purple, with varying luster. Pedicel yellow; anellus brown; flagellum brown. Coxae brown; fore femora yellow or with brownish coloration; mid and hind femora yellow. Fore wing slightly infuscate; venation pale brown. Petiole purple; gaster brown with green to purple luster.

Head: Head width:head height 1.1–1.2; face reticulate; longitudinal groove between eye and torulus absent; eyes bare, inter-ocular distance:eye height 1.4–1.5; malar space:eye height 0.6–0.9; supraclypeal area longer than broad, smooth to weakly sculptured; clypeus smooth. Flagellum length:head height 1.4–1.5; F2 2.5–3.0× as long as broad, 1.1–1.2× as long as F3; following funiculars subequal in width, progressively shorter.

Mesosoma: Mesosoma length:height 1.4. Mesoscutal midlobe reticulate to weakly areolate-reticulate or posteriorly smooth, with minute setae; lateral lobe areolate-reticulate to nearly smooth. Axilla areolate-reticulate; mesoscutellar disc areolate-reticulate; frenal line regularly foveate; frenum areolate-reticulate; axillular groove anteriorly absent, broad and foveate posteriorly; axillula with longitudinal carinae. Propodeum with irregular median carina; propodeal disc areolate to areolate-reticulate; callus reticulate, with 3–5 setae. Mesepisternum reticulate to areolate-reticulate laterally, smooth ventrally, broadly rounded anterior to mid coxa. Upper mesepimeron smooth; lower mesepimeron reticulate; transepimeral sulcus distinct. Metepisternum laterally smooth to reticulate. Hind coxa 2.3–2.4× as long as broad; hind femur 5.4–5.5× as long as broad. Fore wing 2.4– 2.6× as long as broad, 2.7–3.0× as long as mesothorax; stigma with 4 or 5 sensilla in an irregular row. Hind wing costal cell with a broad bare area.
Metasoma: Petiole 2.4–2.6× as long as broad, 0.9–1.0× as long as hind coxa, areolate, anterior carina weak. Antecostal sulcus crossed by carinae; acrosternite posteriorly angulate.

Male. Length 2.2–2.3 mm . Head width:head height 1.2; scape yellow; flagellum length:head height 1.7–2.0, F2 1.8–2.4× as long as broad. Fore femur yellow or with a brownish area, mid and hind femora, and all tibiae yellow. Petiole 5.5–6.2× as long as broad, petiole length:hind coxa length 1.8–1.9.

Discussion. The series of this species found ovipositing into bananas was previously reported as
Orasema costaricensis
by Kerrich (1963) . These specimens, which were morphologically agreeable with one another in having a yellow fore femur and sculptured mesoscutal sidelobes, were designated as holotype and paratypes . Many other specimens with a smooth sidelobe were also present in this series, and were indistinguishable from specimens associated with
Alchornea costaricensis Pax & K.Hoffm.
( Euphorbiaceae ) instead of bananas. We have not been able to obtain sequence data from specimens found ovipositing on either of these plants. Morphologically comparable specimens are tentatively included in this species but were not designated as paratypes . We also have not been able to consistentlyl distinguish specimens that we morphologically attribute to
O. evansi
from Central America and the Caribbean from specimens in the United States ( Fig. 2 , inset) despite their very different behaviors (oviposition into bananas of soft leaves of
A. costaricensis
versus hard leaves of
Quercus
( Fagaceae ) or
Myrica
( Myricaceae ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 61–66.
Orasema evansi
. ♀: form from banana in Costa Rica: 61. Habitus. 62. Head. 63. Antenna, with F2 and F6– F7 inset. 64. Mesosoma, dorsal view. 65. Axillula. 66. Stigma and postmarginal vein.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Biology. The holotype and paratypes were reported as ovipositing into bananas ( Fig. 3 ) by Evans (1968) .
Orasema evansi
(as
O. costaricensis
) was considered enough of a pest in the 1970s that insecticidal treatments were used in an attempt to control the host ants ( Ostmark & Evers 1976 ; Wojcik 1990 ). A series of planidia were collected in Coto, Costa Rica from leaves of mango and citrus that were likely part of the surveys of bananas at that time (see Other Material Examined). While these planidia may not be definitively assignable to
O. evansi
, they are morphologically similar and may attest to a much broader host plant range. Some tentatively assigned (not holotype or paratype ) Costa Rican specimens were collected on leaves of
A. costaricensis
, assigned to
O. costaricensis
based on morphology.

The Texas and Florida populations were reared from
Pheidole dentata
(
Van Pelt 1950
; Heraty 1990, 1994b). Adults were observed ovipositing onto the underside of leaves of small plants of water oak,
Quercus nigra
L. ( Fagaceae ) in Texas (JMH). In Texas (Stubblefield Lake), the host colony of
P. dentata
was found in the soil directly below the host plant in a mixed pine oak forest. Van Pelt reared them from a colony collected in a decayed log of
Pinus palustris Mill.
( Pinaceae ) in a stand of longleaf pine flatwoods. The rate of parasitism of
P. dentata
was reported by Heraty (1994b) , referring to this species as
Orasema
sp. [C1]. Parasitism rates are difficult to measure given the differnt larval stages and potential inclusion of phthisergates, but were as high as 53.5–54.2% of the brood ( Heraty 1994b ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 67–68.
Orasema evansi
. ♀: form from banana in Costa Rica: 67. Propodeum. 68. Petiole.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Immature stages ( Texas population, Fig. 4 ). Egg white, smooth and stalked. ( Fig. 4A ). First instar ( Figs 4B, D, E ). Unfed planidium length 0.26 mm ; after the planidium burrows into the host larva, the first instar swells and the tergites are reduced to bands on the sac-like larva ( Fig. 4D ); shape is retained after the larval exuvium is shed ( Fig. 4E ) and the larva migrates to a ventral position between the legs of the host pupa. In all other respects, the planidium is the same as that of
Orasema delicatula (Walker)
(Burks et al . 2015: Fig. 17 ): antenna absent; labial plates absent; tergopleural line absent; tergites I and II (TI, TII) separate; TI–III with dorsal seta and with wrinklelike longitudinal sculpture; TII and TVI with very short lateral seta; TI, TIII , TV, TVII with ventral seta; TIX with separated leaflike ventral plate having a uniformly curved posterior margin; caudal pad present; caudal cerci present and relatively long, about as long as apical 4 tergites. Second instar ( Fig. 4F ). Smooth dorsally and weakly sculptured ventrally; single thoracic spiracle. Third instar and Prepupa ( Figs 4G, H ). Swollen with lateral tubercles dorsal and ventral to the seven lateral spiracles. Prepupa with six ventral transverse bands of weak sculpture; lateral tubercles and dorsal body segments papillate. Pupa (
Fig. 4I
). Head and mesosoma lacking tubercles; three dorsal tubercles over petiolar region; mesosoma with raised lateral bands and posteriorly with paired dorsal tubercles.

Distribution. Costa Rica , Dominican Republic , Honduras , Nicaragua ,
Panama
, St. Vincent , Trinidad , USA ( Virginia to Texas ).
